Lipschitz function

A Lipschitz function is a function ff such that |f(x)âˆ’f(y)|â‰¤C|xâˆ’y||f(x)-f(y)| \leq C |x-y| for all xx and yy (or for all xx and yy in the set if bound), where CC is a constant independent of xx and yy

(Lipschitz continuous)

more general form:

Given twoÂ metric spacesÂ (X,dX)(X,d_X) and (Y,dY)(Y,d_Y), whereÂ dXd_XÂ denotes theÂ metricÂ on the setÂ XXÂ andÂ dYd_YÂ is the metric on setÂ YY, a functionÂ f:Xâ†’Yf: X â†’ YÂ is calledÂ Lipschitz continuousÂ if there exists a real constantÂ Kâ‰¥0K â‰¥ 0 such that, for allÂ x1x_1 and x2x_2 in XX, dY(f(x1),f(x2))â‰¤KdX(x1,x2)d_Y(f(x_1),f(x_2)) \leq Kd_X(x_1,x_2)

G-Lipschitz

for all ğ±\mathbf{x}, ||âˆ‡f(ğ±)||2â‰¤G||\nabla f(\mathbf{x})||_2 \leq G

(note: norm of gradient, )

Properties:

differentiable at x â‡’ Lipchitz continuous at x â‡’ continuous at x (but the converse is not true)
